title: 110_hr392
content: The Act is titled the "District of Columbia and United States Territories Circulating Quarter Dollar Program Act" and involves the issuance of redesigned quarter dollars honoring the District of Columbia and each of the territories. Section 5112 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include a new subsection for the redesign and issuance of circulating quarter dollars honoring the District of Columbia and the territories in 2009. The designs on the reverse side of the coins will be emblematic of the District of Columbia and the territories, with flexibility in the placement of inscriptions. The redesign and issuance of circulating quarter dollars in 2009 will feature inscriptions on the reverse side and designs emblematic of the District of Columbia and various territories. The redesign and issuance of circulating quarter dollars in 2009 will feature inscriptions on the reverse side and designs emblematic of the District of Columbia and various territories. Each of the 6 designs required for quarter dollars shall be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the chief executive of the District of Columbia or the territory being honored, the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage. The Secretary may include participation by District or territorial officials, artists, engravers, and the general public in the design selection process for quarter dollars. Designs must meet standards of dignity and pride for the Nation's coinage and currency. The Secretary must ensure that no frivolous or inappropriate designs are selected for minting quarter dollars. Designs cannot include head and shoulders portraits or busts of any person, living or dead, or portraits of living individuals. All coins minted under this subsection are considered numismatic items. The Secretary has the authority to mint and issue quarter dollars in uncirculated and proof qualities as determined. The Secretary may mint quarter dollars with 90% silver content in designs selected as appropriate. Coins honoring different territories will be issued in equal intervals during 2009 in a specific order. The subsection outlines provisions for the application of the law in the event of a territory becoming a state or gaining independence. The term 'territory' in this subsection refers to specific regions including the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the United States Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. The House of Representatives passed the legislation on January 23, 2007, as confirmed by Clerk Karen L. Haas.
